title: 109_s1374
content: SEC. 447. BORDER PREPAREDNESS PILOT PROGRAM ON INDIAN LAND is added to Subtitle D of title IV of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enhance border preparedness on Indian land. In this section, "Indian land" is defined as land within Indian reservations or held in trust by the United States for the benefit of Indian tribes or individuals. An "Indian tribe" is defined as any organized group of Native Americans. The Secretary recognizes Indian tribes as eligible for special programs and possessing self-government powers. The purpose is to establish a pilot program for tribal governments near the US border with Canada or Mexico to coordinate responses to security threats. The pilot program aims to enhance the capability of Indian tribes as first responders to illegal border crossings, provide training in surveillance technologies and communication systems, and assist in detecting and preventing illegal entries and transportation of substances on tribal lands. The Secretary will establish a pilot program providing direct grants to eligible tribal governments within 180 days of enactment. Tribal governments must use funds in line with program purposes. The Secretary will administer funds or assistance according to regulations. Selection criteria for tribal governments include proximity to the US border, impact of resources by border enforcement, and tribal interests. Reports are required from tribal governments. Tribal governments receiving funds or assistance must submit annual reports to the Secretary detailing the funds received, their use, and any obstacles encountered in administration. Tribal governments receiving funds or assistance must submit annual reports to the Secretary detailing funds received, their use, and any obstacles encountered in administration. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress within 2 years of the enactment of the Act, describing the success of implementing the pilot program and the projects under it. The pilot program aims to achieve its goals through various projects, with the Secretary providing recommendations, including legislative ones. The section does not affect the authority of the Customs and Border Protection Commissioner or that of participating Indian tribes. Funds allocated are additional to existing ones, and appropriations are authorized for this purpose. Authorization of $3,500,000 for fiscal years 2006-2008 under this Act.
